full_text:
Case 1:20-cr-00330-PAE Document 499-2 Filed 11/23/21 Page 65 of 15964 LBAAMAX3ps Rocchio - Direct
1 sexual abuse. So to the extent that more of my patients are
2 women than men, certainly that's a vulnerability.
3 But also, because, especially now, I'm working with adults, I'm working with people who have been repeatedly
4 victimized at various points in time in their lives. And you
5 can really clearly see the pattern, and it's something I often
6 have to address with patients because they inquire about it,
7 they don't understand. You know, why is it that this has
8 happened to me so many times. And, again, we know from the
9 revictimization literature that when someone is abused, they
10 are at higher risk of being abused at later points in time.
11 Also, you know, sometimes the clinical literature
12 individuals will talk about the specific issues in their family
13 that perhaps increase their vulnerability: They were always
14 alone. They, you know, their mom was sick and this person had
15 lots of opportunity to kind of befriend the family and, you
16 know, therefore had greater access as a result of that
17 vulnerability, or perhaps they were desperate for attention,
18 care, love, and concern from another person because those are
19 common childhood needs and maybe they weren't getting that at
20 home.
21 So those are all the kinds of things that would come
22 up in, and have come up in, my over 30 years of treating
23 patients.
24 Q. In your forensic practice, do you examine the impact of
25 SOUTHERN DISTRICT REPORTERS, P.C. (212) 805-0300 DOJ-OGR-00007933
